translated: Chapter on the Methods of Observing and Violating Precepts (Part 4) Chapter 15: Methods of Observing and Violating Precepts. Before the chapter on Following Characteristics, it is divided according to matters, but as for the general explanation, it is not yet well understood, so it is distinguished. If one
takes the extended path, the principle should be listed first, but I am afraid beginners may not understand it.
In the Vinaya school, there is only observing and violating precepts. The characteristics of observing and violating precepts are truly profound. If one does not accumulate learning, penetrate the
subtle, and exhaust the profound principles, then this meaning is difficult to see!
Therefore, it has been followed through the generations without any other methods;
although there are minor differences in the path, the main point is not contradicted.
However, the newly ordained have not yet mastered the teaching;ğŸ”½when time passes in the academy, how can they know the beginning and end?
If one investigates observing and violating precepts, how can one know them?
However, the text on observing and violating precepts runs through the entire text;
the names are based on the objects, which are already in the chapter on Following Characteristics.
Now I will try to discuss it in general terms based on the meaning, pointing out its main points;
By citing examples to illustrate, it will be easy for those who study it.
Among them, there are various distinctions:

First, knowing the names of upholding and violating, second, understanding the essence, third, clarifying accomplishment, fourth, clarifying the unobstructed, fifth, clarifying gradual and sudden, sixth, clarifying superiority and inferiority, seventh, miscellaneous analysis.
First, clarifying the names of the two kinds of upholding and violating.
First, explaining the two kinds of upholding.
As for the cessation of upholding, it means skillfully and attentively guarding the precepts one has received, restraining body and speech, and not creating any evil. This is called cessation.
Cessation without transgression, the precepts' essence is radiant, in accordance with what one has received, it is called upholding.
Upholding is accomplished through cessation, called the precepts of cessation and upholding, such as those in the first chapter.
Second, clarifying the upholding of action.

Since evil has already been abandoned, one must cultivate goodness, necessarily encouraging the three karmas, cultivating the practice of precepts, and protecting the arising of goodness, which is called action.
Upholding is as explained above.
The reason for the sequence is as stated in the treatise:
The characteristics of precepts are cessation, the characteristics of practice are creation.
It is also said:
The meaning of cessation of evil and practice of good is in sequential order.
Next, the two offenses are explained.

As for the first offense, the five precepts of those who have left the household life, internally possessing the three poisons, the inverted view of self in the mind, agitating body and speech, going against principle and creating objects, is called creation.
Creating and yet having violations, defiling what was originally received, is called offense.
Offense is due to creating, therefore it is called created offense.
This is in contrast to the principle of creating evil dharmas.
Since evil has already been created, one will certainly not cultivate good, therefore the second immediately clarifies the offense of cessation.

As for the offense of cessation, it is because the deluded mind is lazy and negligent, the practice violates the original precepts, and one is averse to cultivating the superior practices, therefore it is called cessation.
Cessation and yet having violations, going against what was originally received, is called offense.
This is in contrast to the principle of not cultivating good dharmas.
Second, the essence and characteristics are clarified.
The other meanings are abandoned;
Speaking directly about correct understanding, there are two ways to identify its essence:
First, in terms of what it upholds, and second, in terms of what it upholds.
As for what it upholds, it takes the mind as its essence, while body and speech are its implements.
Therefore, the treatise says:
These three kinds of karma are all just the mind.
The Vinaya also says:
Endowed with the three kinds of karma, one should carefully observe the mind, and so forth.
As explained later.
Second, in terms of what it upholds.
Upholding and violating both clarify the two teachings.
The prohibitive teaching has two aspects:
First, creation. If one creates, there is no offense. Not following results in a crime.
Second, prohibition. If one creates, there is an offense. If one stops, there is no violation.
As for the permissive teaching, creating or not creating, there is no crime at all.
Why are the two necessary?
If there is only prohibition without allowance, those of medium and lower abilities will have no way to progress on the path.

If there were only opening without restriction, the superior practice would be arrogant and seeking, and self-encouragement would cease. Therefore, both teachings are necessary to fully encompass the meaning of subduing beings.
Now, dividing the two teachings, the scope of subsuming the Dharma;
The observance of prohibitions and the violation of precepts are only clarified in relation to the matters within the two teachings;
The observance of precepts and the violation of prohibitions are common to both the Dharma and matters of the two teachings.
The reason why the Dharma was not included before is because the Dharma is only known through progressive cultivation;
Matters are only to be avoided and naturally included, so they can be clarified.
In the previous observance of prohibitions, in relation to the two teachings, there are two matters in the prohibitive aspect:
First, what can be learned and prohibited, such as sexual misconduct with the three types of objects, stealing from the four types of owners, etc.;
Second, what is prohibited, such as the size and material of robes and alms bowls, etc.

Second, matters that cannot be learned, due to the delusion and confusion of the mind, not yet understanding according to the circumstances, etc., this is the abandoned meaning of the past. In the past, it was said that matters cannot be learned, but now it is said that the deluded and forgetful mind cannot learn.
All mental states and objects are to be learned;
But if one is deluded and not yet enlightened, the Buddha opens up everything for them.
As for the listening aspect, the matters apply to the upper two [categories]:
As for what can be learned, such as the dimensions of dwellings and the size of long robes,
What cannot be learned is the same as described above;
But due to delusion and forgetfulness, there is no violation of the teachings;
The thoughts before and after change, so the conclusion is indeterminate.
Next, the practice of upholding.
In the aspect of prohibitions, it is compared to the Dharma and matters.
The Dharma refers to the teachings and practices; the teachings refer to the Vinaya canon, and the practices refer to the antidotes;
The matters are only what can be learned, such as the substance and dimensions of robes and alms bowls.
In the aspect of listening, it is also compared to the Dharma and matters.
The Dharma refers to the permission to designate pure lands, etc.;
The matters are only what can be learned, such as long robes, dwellings, etc.
The reason why it does not apply to what cannot be learned is because the mind is deluded and forgetful, and learning cannot understand it; it is explained in detail later.
This means that in accordance with the teachings, one acts without transgression, and therefore they are all called upholding through performance.
Third, it clarifies the offenses committed through performance, which is the opposite of upholding through restraint.
However, if one does not follow the precepts and creates actions that are accomplished, they are all called offenses committed through performance.
Fourth, it clarifies the offenses committed through non-performance, which is the opposite of upholding through performance.
The corresponding dharmas and matters, as well as being lazy and not learning, are all included.
Third, it clarifies the places where one can accomplish [the precepts].
First, it is discussed in terms of the mind.
There are two kinds of upholding through restraint.
The first is the clear upholding through restraint without evil coming to defile.
The three minds before engaging in practice can have upholding through restraint, referring to cognition, conception, and feeling, etc.
These three are not karmic actions;
They flow into the mind of practice and only then become a separate cause.
Therefore, they are divided into two.
Due to originally having a pure precept nature, without transgression it is called upholding.
The nature of receiving [the precepts] is indeterminate, and the three minds are indeterminate.
Second, it clarifies the upholding through restraint in terms of the practice of counteracting [defilements].
Upholding through performance must be accomplished with the mind of practice, but the first three do not have it;
If it is wholesome, then there is [wholesome volition], but if it is unwholesome or indeterminate, there is none.

As for the two types of offenses of abstention and performance, the volition is accomplished. Previously, in the case of observance, the three of non-greed, etc. were the practice. Now, in the case of offenses, the three of greed, hatred, etc. are the practice. The previous three also do not have the three mental factors of consciousness, conception, and feeling;
They are limited to the unwholesome nature.
If there are separate observances and offenses in the subsequent and prior minds, the reasons can be known.
The latter three clarify accomplishment through action.
As for the two observances of the body, avoiding killing and other faults is called the observance of abstention of the body;
Accepting food and eating, etc. is called the observance of performance of the body.
As for the two observances of speech, avoiding the four faults of speech is called abstention;
Knowing pure speech, etc. is called performance.
The two offenses of body and speech are the opposite of the above and should be known.
In the case of the single mental action, observance and offense are not accomplished;
If one moves the body and speech, volition also accomplishes observance and offense.
This will be explained later.
Fourth, clarifying the unobstructed.
It is divided into four aspects.
Each aspect is a mental factor.
Only by clarifying it in terms of practice can it be blocked and not allowed to pass;
because the mind does not consider things simultaneously, and the objects do not appear suddenly.
Second, comparing the mind to the objects.
There is both blockage and passage.
As for blockage, upholding and violating do not exist together;
as for passage, upholding and violating are mutually inclusive.
For example, within the upholding of cessation there is the upholding of activity, and within the upholding of activity there is the upholding of cessation;
the two violations are also like this.
If one wishes to take the distinctions,
the answer is:
within cessation there is activity, which includes activity within cessation;
it is the same within activity.
Raising the principle is clear, how could it be vague?

First, the mind of upholding cessation and activity is different; second, the objects of upholding cessation and activity are different; third, the mind of cessation corresponds to the objects of activity; fourth, the mind of activity corresponds to the objects of cessation.
If one explains the upholding of cessation in terms of cultivation, it is like first cultivating practices such as compassion and few desires in order to stop killing and stealing;
because the practices are accomplished, it is called the upholding of activity;
looking at the objects without arising is called the upholding of cessation;
The stopping is the doing.
If we explain the upholding of the precepts in terms of cultivation, it is like wanting to recite the precepts and karman, first stopping external conditions;
Awaiting the separation from coarse faults is called stopping;
Later, the accomplishment of good practice is called doing;
The stopping is within the doing.
There is stopping offense on the side of the mind of doing offense, like a person doing evil, first not learning goodness, this is the kind.
There is doing offense in the mind of stopping offense, like a person keeping extra robes beyond the day, building a hut without asking for permission.
If we look at not learning, stopping offense, there is no doing offense;
Not immediately accomplishing each other, it is not without later practice.
Third, explaining doing oneself and instructing others, the four statements all apply.
Like the mind instructing a person to filter water for one's own use, this is upholding by stopping;
Instructing a person to hold the desire to speak in the assembly, this is upholding by doing;
Instructing a person to teach the living;
Also not asking for permission, sending a person to build a hut.
After performing the four actions, the subsequent mind intends to be free from faults.
Within the practice of abstention, there is abstention from abstention up to abstention from transgression.
Even within the mind of abstention from transgression, both abstention and observance are complete.
As before, after dispatching someone to perform the four aspects, one then abstains from learning good dharmas.
Fourth, the four preceding and subsequent self-actions mutually accomplish.
There are obstructions and there are openings.
Obstructions are easy to understand;
Openings require skillful means. The four fours and sixteen are no different from before, but the characteristics are slightly different.
As before, oneself setting up a filter, forbidding a novice monk, setting up a killing device, closing the door and showing signs without giving consent;
After performing these four, one then cultivates abstention up to abstention from transgression.
These last two methods both cultivate and create in relation to matters, clarifying abstention from transgression.
Fifth, clarifying gradual and sudden.
First, in terms of the mind, there is gradual and sudden.
If one intends to completely sever evil, it is called the sudden mind of abstention;
If one wishes to commit all evil deeds, it is called a sudden mind of committing offenses.ğŸ”½If one cultivates all wholesome deeds, it is called a sudden mind of observing precepts.
If one ceases cultivation, it is called a sudden mind of committing offenses.
As for gradual mind, it can be understood by analogy.
Since they are all in violation or compliance with the precepts, observing and violating are divided into two parts.
Second, it is explained in terms of practice.
It is only gradual, not sudden.
Because in one practice, one cannot cultivate the other practices, observing precepts is called gradual.
As for gradual observing precepts, when cultivating the mind of loving-kindness, one cannot cultivate other countermeasures;
Violating precepts is only gradual, because one cannot suddenly violate all precepts.
For example, if a man intends to kill, if he kills out of greed, he only violates one precept;
The six precepts against killing, the forty-nine precepts, the fifty-six precepts, etc., are not violated at all.
They are all as explained above.
Third, it is explained in terms of violating precepts in the precepts of individual liberation.
The four statements distinguish them.
First, the sin of not learning and the sin of ignorance are explained in terms of gradual and sudden.
The sin of not learning arises first;
The sin of ignorance arises later because it is based on not understanding.
The text says:
If one does not recite the precepts and karman for five years, one then commits a sin.
Second, the sin of not learning in the prÄtimoká¹£a has both gradual and sudden.
If one vows to learn the objects, but has the intention of not learning, one suddenly commits the sin of not learning in each individual dharma.
Because one receives it at the beginning and obtains it through generating it;
It causes one to violate the essence of the vow and suddenly receive many sins.
How is it gradual?
If one vows not to learn the karman, but to learn everything else;
In relation to the karman, one commits one sin of cessation, which is called gradual.
If one discusses ignorance, it is only gradual, meaning that one is only bound by the sin of ignorance based on not understanding;
One mind does not fully prepare the conditions, so it is only gradual.
Question:
What are the two offenses of not learning and ignorance?
Answer:
Some say they are both minor offenses.
Now, the explanation says that not learning is a minor offense.
Ignorance has two types. If it is completely fundamental ignorance, one gets the heavy offense. Therefore, the Vinaya says:
Heavily increasing the ignorance offense of pÄrÄjika.
If it is doubt, one gets the light offense, which is a minor offense.
The three time periods.
Based on the teachings, in relation to practice, and from the faculties, there are three distinctions.
As for the teachings, learning is based on the beginning and end, and not learning is immediately concluded;
The offense of ignorance is concluded after five summers.
In relation to practice, fearing the mind will be unrestrained, self-confident in little understanding, and hoping to equal the sages;
Therefore, learning is common throughout one's life, with differences in superiority and inferiority.
The text says:
A five-year-old wise bhiká¹£u should receive guidance from a ten-year-old wise bhiká¹£u;
Up to the establishment of the five parts of the Dharma body, one then leaves guidance.
As for the faculties,
If one has sharp faculties and is easily enlightened, one has ignorance due to not learning regarding the two offenses at the beginning and end.
If one has dull faculties and is difficult to enlighten, one has no offense of ignorance regarding not learning at the beginning and end, because it is not within one's capacity.
The Vinaya says:
A foolish bhiká¹£u should rely on [a teacher] for the rest of his life.
Are the four [types of offenses] that can be confessed all the same?
Both can be confessed.
If one does not learn and later does not understand, one commits the offense of ignorance.
If one learns with a determined mind but does not yet understand, one does not commit the offense of ignorance. The offense of ignorance from not learning before has the meaning of being eliminated.
All can be confessed.
Sixth, clarifying the superiority and inferiority of upholding and violating.
First, clarifying the two kinds of upholding in ten aspects.
First, in terms of the Dharma.
There are four different kinds:
1. Precepts of deportment, 2. Precepts of guarding the faculties, 3. Precepts shared with concentration, 4. Precepts shared with the path.
The first is the precepts of a monk in name only in the outer stage of faith;
The middle two are the precepts of a monk in union in the inner stage of faith;
The last one is the precepts of a true monk in the stage of sagehood.
The superiority and inferiority of virtue and conduct differ in three grades;
Upholding the precepts is weak, while protecting the faculties and upholding the precepts is superior, because it restrains the mind, and up to the precepts concomitant with the path are superior.
Second, in terms of stage.
The precepts of a person beyond training are superior because their virtue is complete;
The precepts of the three fruits are inferior because their pursuit has not yet ceased.
The precepts of the inner and outer disciples are gradually weaker when compared.
Third, in terms of person.
The precepts of the seven assemblies are superior up to the precepts of a great bhiká¹£u, and the Vinaya of no more learning is the most superior.
Fourth, in terms of practice.

Upholding the precepts of abstinence is superior in avoiding grave offenses, while upholding the precepts of performance is inferior in avoiding minor offenses, this is the comparison of light and heavy.
If one is able to practice the remedy, then upholding the precepts of abstinence is inferior because it is against coarse offenses and the practice of the remedy is easily accomplished;
Upholding the precepts of performance is superior because it is against subtle offenses and the practice of the remedy is difficult to accomplish.
Fifth, in terms of mind.
There are three:

First, a wholesome mind upholding precepts, referring to cultivating pure conduct free from defilements, such as being unstained by the three periods of time when facing the root offenses and enemies.
An unwholesome mind refers to upholding precepts for fame, profit, worldly rewards, etc.
A neutral mind refers to insanity, sleep, etc.
If compared based on practice, the upper, middle, and lower levels are not equal.
If compared based on following the teachings, all uphold precepts and are not divided into three minds.
Sixth, based on what is sought, there are four kinds:
First, the limit of thieves, such as flattery, wrong livelihood, surpassing others for fame and profit, etc.
Second, the limit of offenses, fearing falling into the three evil paths.
The Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra says:
The practitioner's deep mind does not enjoy doing evil, which is called pure upholding of precepts.
Third, the limit of blessings, wishing to be born in the heavens and receive happiness, etc.
Fourth, the limit of the path, because liberation is attained through precepts due to the bonds and attachments, etc.
Seventh, upholding based on directions.
JambudvÄ«pa is superior, because afflictions are heavy there;
in the west and east, upholding precepts is weak.
Eighth, in terms of the presence or absence of the Buddha.
When the Buddha was present, it was superior; after his extinction, it was inferior.
In the true Dharma, semblance Dharma, and final Dharma periods, it gradually weakened.
Using UpÄli's questioning of the nuns as evidence;
in the Buddha's time, the group of six were extremely coarse and violent;
after his extinction, those beyond training did not match their deportment.
Ninth, in terms of proscribed and essential precepts.
The two precepts are different, mutually upholding strength and weakness.
The sixteen categories of precepts, superior and inferior, mutually uphold strength and weakness.
Next, clarifying the two offenses, the superiority and inferiority of the ten approaches.
First, in terms of the distinction of stages.
Because those beyond training err in violation, it is light; because those in the three fruits violate, it is heavy.
Those in the three fruits have strong, pure power; although they violate, it is still light; those in the inner stages of the path are inferior, so it is heavy.
Up to those in the outer stages of the path, the comparison can be known.
Second, in terms of practitioners.
Commissioned offenses are heavy; prohibited offenses are light.
It can also be said that intentional offenses are serious, while unintentional ones are light.
Third, the superiority and inferiority are distinguished based on the three grades of mental states.
As in the first chapter of the scroll, they are divided into three natures.
Fourth, the precepts and deportment.
The relative heaviness and lightness of the chapters and categories can be known.
Fifth, the relative heaviness and lightness are distinguished based on whether they are proscribed or essential.
Because of violating the essential precepts, the hell offenses cannot be removed, as stated in the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom.
Sixth, based on time.
Distinguishing the relative heaviness and lightness of offenses before and after the Buddha, as can be understood in the chapter on upholding the precepts.
Seventh, comparing the mind to the object.
As the MÄtá¹›kÄ-sÅ«tra says:
Offenses must rely on objects, and the mind forms karma.

This is because the mind has degrees of intensity and the objects have degrees of superiority and inferiority.ğŸ”½Sometimes the mind and object are both serious, such as a person killing a person with the thought of a person;ğŸ”½sometimes the object is serious but the mind is light, such as a person killing a non-person with the thought of a non-person;
sometimes the object is light but the mind is serious, such as a non-person killing a person with the thought of a person.
The treatise applies to all, not just one precept.
Within sexual misconduct, there are also degrees of seriousness:
animals and humans;
Among humans, there are lay and monastic;
Among the lay, there are those who keep precepts and those who break precepts, and among the monastic, there are the five groups who keep precepts and those who break precepts;
Up to the sages.
The offenses are the same, but the retributions are different.
The second grave offense of stealing.
Celestials and humans, up to sages;
The distinctions of the Three Jewels, the property of the Saá¹…gha is the most grave.
The third precept against killing.
The Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra says:
As the Abhidharma of the Six-Foot Canon states, killing those with wrong views is lighter than killing insects;
Because these people pollute the world and cause much harm.
The fourth precept.
It is said to be grave for those who are lay, and light for those who are monastic.
The eight precepts are established to regulate retribution, clarifying the light and grave.
As the MÄtá¹›kÄ-vibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra says:
Like the three precepts of matchmaking and lodging, people are prone to violate them;ğŸ”½The Vinaya rules against emotional faults, therefore they are established as grave offenses;
Since they are prohibited evils, the retribution is not grave. Therefore the ÅšÄstra says:
The methods of establishing precepts are different, with light offenses being called heavy names;
The methods of incurring offenses are different, with cause and effect corresponding.
Sometimes the offense is light but the retribution is heavy, such as the natural offenses of striking a bhiká¹£u, etc.;
The meaning is rare, so the Vinaya establishes a light name;
Since it is the mind going against principle as the karma, the heavy retribution is also heavy. Therefore the treatise says:
The methods of establishing precepts are different, with heavy offenses being called light names;
The methods of incurring offenses are different, with cause and effect corresponding.
Sometimes the offense and retribution are both heavy, such as emission of semen, the two kinds of slander, etc.;
Sometimes the offense and retribution are both light, such as the bodily and verbal deportment that is not remembered, forgotten errors, or offenses committed with a sense of shame.

The last two sentences conclude that the methods of establishing precepts are not different from the methods of incurring offenses, and the methods of incurring offenses are not different from the methods of establishing precepts.
The ninth is the single mind and the three periods, distinguishing the lightness and heaviness of offenses.
According to the Sutra of Good Increase, it is about the precept against killing, with eight sentences of lightness and heaviness, divided into four categories.
The first sentence, the three periods are all heavy:

That is, in the preparatory stage, one raises a mind of extreme harm; in the fundamental stage, one gives rise to a mind of extreme delight; in the subsequent stage, one gives rise to a mind of rejoicing.

The second set of three statements has two heavy and one light:ğŸ”½The first says the preparatory and fundamental stages are heavy, and the subsequent stage is light;ğŸ”½The middle says the preparatory stage is light, and the fundamental and subsequent stages are heavy;
The last says the preparatory and subsequent stages are heavy, and the fundamental stage is light.
The third set of three statements has one heavy and two light:
The first says the fundamental stage is heavy, and the preparatory and subsequent stages are light;ğŸ”½The middle says the preparatory stage is heavy, and the middle and subsequent stages are light;
The last says the subsequent stage is heavy, and the preparatory and fundamental stages are light.
The fourth statement has all three stages being light:
Like in the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika Vinaya, where an ignorant elder, out of compassion, teaches someone to kill,

In the Ká¹£emaá¹…kara and Ten Recitations Vinayas, where crying kills one's parents, out of fear of suffering, harms the lives of one's parents, and so on. The Vinaya takes the perception of a person as the basis, and all eight actions are heavy;
Because karma follows the mind, the retribution it attracts is not the same.
Therefore, the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra says:
Deeply entangled, killing an ant is serious; with compassionate mind, killing a person is light.
10. With or without mind.
The eight statements corresponding to each other have four positions as before.
The first statement has a mind at the three times.
The next three statements:
1. The first and middle have a mind, but the end does not have a mind, and one commits the four grave offenses;
2. The beginning does not have a mind, but the middle and end have a mind, and one also commits the four grave offenses;
3. The beginning and end have a mind, but the middle does not have a mind, and one commits the first grave offense, and the other three precepts are thullaccaya and duá¹£ká¹›ta.
The last three statements:

1. The middle has a mind, but the beginning and end do not have a mind, and one commits the four grave offenses;ğŸ”½2. The beginning immediately has a mind, but the middle and end do not have a mind, and one commits the first grave offense, and the other three precepts are either thullaccaya or duá¹£ká¹›ta;

3. The end immediately has a mind, but the upper two do not have a mind. The precept against sexual misconduct is committed as a grave offense because there is pleasure when leaving. If the other three are committed, it is duá¹£ká¹›ta.
The next sentence:
If there is no mind at the three times, there is no offense.
Therefore, in the Vinaya, one should think like this: I will tell a lie.
The latter eight sentences are distinguished by whether there is an offense due to the presence or absence of mind;
They are not the same as the first eight, all of which involve mind.
The explanation of the absence of mind refers to either the absence of a mind that experiences pleasure or a mind that kills, steals, etc., or to one who is insane and unaware.
In the miscellaneous detailed analysis, there are five parts:

First, the distinction of positions based on ignorance due to lack of learning; second, the distinction of the approach to fruition; third, the distinction of the completion of offenses based on the necessary conditions; fourth, the distinction of perceptions of objects;
Fifth, the distinction of miscellaneous characteristics.
The first, ignorance due to lack of learning, is subtle and hidden.
First, it is summarized and concluded, and then it is given as an example.

As for the characteristics of offenses, it refers to those who, after receiving the precepts, diligently study the Tripiá¹­aka, who are confused and forgetful regarding objects, and who create offenses when encountering conditions;
The characteristics of the objects and perceptions are complete.
If one has not studied and is ignorant of the precepts and dharmas, and thus violates them,
the Buddha said:
According to what one has done, one commits the fundamental offense, and further increases the offense of ignorance.
Having briefly explained the precepts, one should match them with the methods of practice.
Now, two sets of nine statements are established as the standard for observing and violating precepts;
taking one matter as an example, it extends to the other precepts.
First, regarding the observance of precepts, clarifying the distinction between light and heavy offenses.
First, clarifying the matters that can be learned.
Nine statements are made, divided into three grades.
The highest grade is one statement:
Knowing the matter and knowing the violation.
The middle grade has four statements:

The first is knowing the matter but doubting the violation, the second is knowing the matter but not knowing the violation, the third is knowing the violation but doubting the matter, and the fourth is knowing the violation but not knowing the matter.
The lowest grade has four statements:

The first is doubting the matter and doubting the violation, the second is doubting the matter but not knowing the violation, the third is not knowing the matter but doubting the violation, and the fourth is not knowing the matter and not knowing the violation.
Next, in the explanation, it is said that those who do not recognize are those who violate what is not a violation, and those who are confused about light offenses considering them heavy.
The same is true for doubts, doubting whether there is or is not, doubting whether it is light or heavy.
Because those of the upper level recognize both, they do not have the offense of not learning or not knowing.

Because those of the middle level have recognition, they give rise to doubts and do not recognize regarding the offense and the matter, thus there are eight offenses, each with not learning or not knowing.
The lower level has four sentences and sixteen offenses.
Among these twenty-four offenses, there are six pÄyattikas and eighteen duá¹£ká¹›tas, because of not knowing, one obtains the heavy [offenses].
The remaining doubts and those who do not learn are all duá¹£ká¹›tas.
They do not violate the fundamental, which is called the observance of cessation.
Because those of the upper level recognize both, it is called the upper level observance of cessation.
Because the offenses of the middle level are few, it is called the middle level observance of cessation.
Because the lower level is extremely numerous, it is called the lower level.
